The early Mainframe computer systems utilized tubes, not transistors. To restore a Mainframe laptop or computer necessary a diploma in Electronics. The technician needed to know how to measure current, voltage, resistance, and wattage. The Mainframe had 'Banks' or 'racks' stuffed with tubes that switched, managed, enhanced, or lessen voltage and amperage even though performing its work of running a system. Every single tube would now be regarded as a transistor, the difference is a transistor in a processor is either on or off, that is it has a constructive charge or no cost. Tubes will not operate this way, the tube has to have a selected quantity of current present to change the bias from positive to negative. Therefore YOU could not fix your Mainframe without a Degree due to the fact changing a tube with the incorrect portion would fry the Mainframe and possibly you as well! When the very first Computer was released from IBM (who made and nevertheless makes Mainframes) the tradition of only a Technician/Engineer with a degree and Tie could restore a pc was carried around, for a although anyway.
